net.slightlymagic.braids.util.progress_monitor
Class BaseProgressMonitor

java.lang.Object
  net.slightlymagic.braids.util.progress_monitor.BaseProgressMonitor
All Implemented Interfaces:
BraidsProgressMonitor
Direct Known Subclasses:
MultiPhaseProgressMonitorWithETA, StderrProgressMonitor
public class BaseProgressMonitor
extends Object
implements BraidsProgressMonitor

This base class also acts as a "null" progress monitor; it doesn't display anything when updated. Absolute times are measured in seconds, in congruence with ProgressMonitor.

See Also:
BraidsProgressMonitor

BaseProgressMonitor

public BaseProgressMonitor(int numPhases,
                           long totalUnitsFirstPhase,
                           float minUIUpdateIntervalSec,
                           float[] phaseWeights)
Initializes fields and starts the timers.

Parameters:
numPhases - the total number of phases we will monitor
totalUnitsFirstPhase - how many units to expect in phase 1
minUIUpdateIntervalSec - the approximate interval at which we update the user interface, in seconds
phaseWeights - may be null; if not null, this indicates the relative weight of each phase in terms of time to complete all phases. Index 0 of this array indicates phase 1's weight, index 1 indicates the weight of phase 2, and so on. If null, all phases are considered to take an equal amount of time to complete, which is equivalent to setting all phase weights to 1.0f. For example, if there are two phases, and the phase weights are set to {2.0f, 1.0f}, then the methods that compute the final ETA (Estimated Time of Arrival or completion) will assume that phase 2 takes half as long as phase 1. In other words, the operation will spend 67% of its time in phase 1, and 33% of its time in phase 2.

justUpdatedUI

protected void justUpdatedUI()
Subclasses must call this immediately after updating the UI, to preserve the integrity of the shouldUpdateUI method.

shouldUpdateUI

public boolean shouldUpdateUI()
Description copied from interface: BraidsProgressMonitor
Returns a boolean, whether or not to display the updated information. This throttles the update so it doesn't refresh so fast that it is unreadable. Implementers should call this method from their own incrementUnitsCompletedThisPhase method. If we have just reached 100% for (the current phase, we return true, even if it would otherwise be too soon to update the UI.

Specified by:
shouldUpdateUI in interface BraidsProgressMonitor
See Also:
BraidsProgressMonitor.shouldUpdateUI()

markCurrentPhaseAsComplete

public void markCurrentPhaseAsComplete(long totalUnitsNextPhase)
Description copied from interface: BraidsProgressMonitor
This is the only way to advance the phase number. It automatically "starts the clock" for the next phase.

Specified by:
markCurrentPhaseAsComplete in interface BraidsProgressMonitor
Parameters:
totalUnitsNextPhase - if unknown, use zero (0), and be sure to call setTotalUnitsThisPhase() soon after.
See Also:
BraidsProgressMonitor.markCurrentPhaseAsComplete(long)

sendMessage in interface BraidsProgressMonitor
Parameters:
message - the message to display

BraidsProgressMonitor.sendMessage(java.lang.String)

setCurrentPhaseAsExponential

public void setCurrentPhaseAsExponential(float value)
Description copied from interface: BraidsProgressMonitor
Mark the current phase as having an exponential rate; such phases reach their totalUnits slower and slower as they process more units. By default, a phase is considered to be linear, meaning this value is 1.0f.

Specified by:
setCurrentPhaseAsExponential in interface BraidsProgressMonitor
Parameters:
value - usually less than 1.0f; often determined empirically.
See Also:
BraidsProgressMonitor.setCurrentPhaseAsExponential(float)

the exponent for this phase
